reviews.review_msg: A lot of reading, but you can tell that she cares about her students and is invested in their success. Would recommend seeing her during office hours for papers and assignments, I found her very helpful both in and outside of class. Definitely passionate about her job!

Gerson seems unapproachable at first but is really quite friendly. The first few readings for this course are extremely long and dry but get progressively better. She's extremely well read, very professional, intelligent, and kind. Clearly very passionate about Canadian Literature. However, lectures can go off on seemingly insignificant tangents.

Great prof who genuinely cares about her students, and works hard to make the class interesting and assignments fun. Only drawback was that students' differing opinions weren't taken too well (her insights were invaluable, but I think her teaching goals limited class discussion at times). She just wanted to convince everyone of her own readings.

Paul is passionate and genuinely seems to enjoy teaching. He is helpful a sense that he offers extensive feedback on essays and assignments to help you do better next time. He is also an easy marker, oh, and there's no need to attend every class, participation matters but you'll get  a decent mark without going to every class.

he is my favourite prof of all time.  besides being a nice man, he is incredibly intelligent and passionate about his subject matter.  for papers be as creative as you can, he loves anything that is different and offbeat and if you can include some references to pop culture you are good as gold.

I love this prof and this class so much I am taking another class with him next term! Admittedly, he is eccentric, but is that really a bad thing? He knows his material and he is passionate about it. He is also more than fair in his grading and his comments on returned assignments couldn't be any more helpful.

This professor likes to look sweet. However, he acts weird and projects nervousness that is unnerving and unsettling to be a part of. He tends to criticize the English department quite vocally and yet he manages to remain very much one of the "establishment".  One wonders how he manages this dual identity.  He definately lacks discretion.

Great prof. Comes across as a bit of dragon lady at first, but this is a ruse... she's a sweetheart. Go to her office hours and chat with her, find a paper topic that really interests you, and then run with it. She's perpetually disorganized, and can't figure out the AV stuff for love or money, but she's fantastic. Really first rate.

A lot of WebCT. A ridiculous amount of biographical information on authors. Little to no engaging textual analysis. Talks the class away with her favourite students about things that have no bearing on the course at all. Unclear assignment guidelines. You end up paying for her disorganization with your grade.

Try to avoid taking a class with her. Overly picky about grammar, bibliographies and other minute details. Always stressed out and full of excuses as to why she wasn't prepared for class. Maybe she's a smart lady, but she shouldn't be teaching.

She is a kind woman, however, the class was MORE than disorganized.  She would often miss classes, show up late, and was NEVER prepared for lecture.  She was constantly revising the course outline on webct because she could never get the internet readings to us on time--sometimes she would post them the night before, othertimes the morning of.

Karyn is very intelligent, but her knowledge of the subject doesn't come through in her lecture. Seminars are long, pay attention to grammar, books aren't done justice by her lectures, takes attendance, lots of webct and exercises, critical reviews, etc. high maintenance prof and course. Feels like a book club - no intelligent discussion.
She is a really nice person and very helpful...
